prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

head.headtext: The Quality of Confidence—Availability within the industry

para.paratext: The Canadian courts have confirmed that information will not be considered confidential where it can be properly acquired elsewhere within the relevant trade or industry. In Cooperheat of Canada Ltd. v. Slater,[1] the court considered, on a motion to extend an ex parte interim injunction, whether an employee had misused confidential information. The judge refused to continue the injunction on the basis that:

I am not satisfied that the details of this welding equipment falls within the class of confidential information. There appears to be evidence that this type of welding … equipment … is commonly known and has been commonly known for many years, and … can be purchased from competitors.

I think there is a substantial area of disagreement as to whether or not this welding equipment is really of such a peculiar or difficult nature that its manufacturer would fall within the ambit of the general phrase “secret” or “confidential”.[2]
(Emphasis added.)

Further Canadian decisions, such as Consolidated Textiles Ltd. v. Central Dynamics Ltd.[3] and Bendix Home Systems Ltd. v. Clayton,[4] have taken the same approach. In Bendix, the Supreme Court of British Columbia held that there can be no disclosure of confidential information where information is generally “within the knowledge of the knowledgeable people in the industry or would be matters which could be ascertained on inquiry”. However, on the other hand, where some or all of the constituent elements are widely known within the industry, but the whole represents a “unique combination of elements”, the subject-matter may be held to constitute confidential information.[5]

Although the case was ultimately decided against the defendants on the basis of a restrictive covenant, Cradle Pictures (Canada) Ltd. v. Penner[6] held that there will be no misuse of confidential information where:

… the techniques and equipment used in the business were of a kind known to and available with only slight modification to any professional photographer, the package of photographs and materials offered for sale could easily be duplicated by one with rudimentary skills in the trade, without any special knowledge or prior advantage of association with the plaintiff's business.

… I find there to be nothing in the nature of confidential information intrinsically related to the client hospitals … Nor is there a question here of confidentiality of a customer list. The potential customers of this service are limited, and listed in a directory.[7]
(Emphasis added.)

Trade secrets and confidential business methodologies and other information must not be of a general nature but rather must be specific. Information that is extensively known to the other members of the trade is not protectable. In Plaza Consulting Inc. v. Grieve,[8] despite strenuous assertions about the breach of duty of confidentiality by the former employees or consultants of the Plaintiff, no reliable evidence existed that any confidential information was actually taken. The Plaintiff's marketing strategies, business approaches, training methods, and its much-vaunted DPA, could only be seen as highly generic. Its “training curriculum” appeared to be copied from a publicly available book, while its recruiting methods were to seek out the “brightest” and “smartest” students from university programs and to give them a test which it borrowed from a freely available internet site.[9] The plaintiff's evidence confirmed that the most innovative parts of its business were the labels put onto what were otherwise widely shared approaches in the technology consultant industry.[10]
However, each case is unique, as one court has held that an analysis performed on publicly available data can constitute confidential information.[11]
